title: Twitter Stock: Is It A Buy Right Now? Here's What Earnings, TWTR Stock Chart Show
summary:
XAmid the current coronavirus stock market rally, is the stock a buy right now?
Twitter Stock News And FundamentalsOn March 9, Twitter reached an agreement with activist investors who have pressured the company to make changes.
What The IBD Stock Checkup Says About Twitter StockAccording to the IBD Stock Checkup, Twitter stock has a 75 out of a highest-possible 99 IBD Composite Rating.
In conclusion, Twitter stock is not a buy right now in the coronavirus stock market rally amid significant weakness in stock price, but watch the stock to see if it continues to build its base.
For more leading stocks and stocks approaching buy points, check out these IBD Stock Lists, like the Stocks Near Buy Zones.
text:
After a much-hyped IPO in November 2013, social media giant Twitter (TWTR) has struggled to maintain any significant stock price appreciation. Plus, Twitter's feud with President Trump continues to escalate.

X

Amid the current coronavirus stock market rally, is the stock a buy right now?

Twitter is a social networking service that allows users to post and interact with messages known as "tweets." Twitter competes with the likes of FANG stock Facebook (FB) and re-emergent Snap (SNAP).

Twitter generates money from selling ads to businesses. The company is attempting to become the go-to source of updates for live events, including sports, breaking news and entertainment. Higher traffic and engagement levels will increase ad demand on Twitter, boosting ad prices and the company's sales.

Many pro sports have already suspended their regular seasons indefinitely, including the NBA and NHL, due to the spreading coronavirus outbreak. Tweets during live sports, especially the NBA, are a key driver of Twitter traffic.

Twitter Stock News And Fundamentals

On March 9, Twitter reached an agreement with activist investors who have pressured the company to make changes. The company agreed to a $2 billion share repurchase program, among other things.

In the most recent quarter — reported on April 30 — earnings declined 70% to 11 cents per share. Revenue, meanwhile, grew 3% year over year to $807.6 billion. First-quarter earnings were in line with Wall Street estimates while revenue beat despite the coronavirus crisis taking a toll on advertising overall.

Average monetizable daily active users were 166 million for the first quarter vs. 152 million in the fourth quarter. From the year earlier period user growth jumped 24%. That's the fastest growth since Twitter began reporting the metric in 2016.

Late Thursday, Twitter flagged a tweet from President Trump for "glorifying violence." According to the company, "We've taken action in the interest of preventing others from being inspired to commit violent acts, but have kept the Tweet on Twitter because it is important that the public still be able to see the Tweet given its relevance to ongoing matters of public importance."

Friday's action is the latest exchange in the ongoing confrontation between Twitter and the president. On Thursday, Trump signed an executive order on online platforms. The order urges tightened oversight on social media companies, which currently police their own content without fear of lawsuits related to comments, videos and other content posted by users on their platforms.

The Twitter Stock Chart

Twitter stock broke out above a 41.02 buy point in a cup with handle on July 26, 2019, after the company's Q2 results. At its Sept. 9 peak, shares had risen as much as 11.8% from the entry. But those gains proved to be short-lived, as the stock pulled back and fell below its 50-day moving average line.

On Oct. 23, the stock triggered the 7%-8% loss-cutting sell rule from the 41.02 entry. Just one day later, shares plunged 20% on Oct. 24 on the company's earnings results.

After falling as much as 38% from its 52-week high on Nov. 7, shares started to rally, capped off by a 15% surge on Feb. 6. But amid the coronavirus stock market correction, the stock price crashed to 52-week lows.

On April 8, Twitter surged about 10% after Bernstein upgraded the stock from underperform to market perform with a 29 price target. Analyst Mark Shmulik ended his bearish call due to the popularity of Twitter's platform during the coronavirus outbreak. According to the research note, Twitter "sits at the fulcrum of news and conversation during this unprecedented global event."

A new base could be forming, but there is no buy point in sight. Shares are rebounding but are about 30% off their 52-week high. Shares regained their long-term 200-day line on May 26, but are back below that key level.

On May 29, shares dove more than 4% before trimming losses to 2% after the company escalated its feud with President Trump. On Thursday night, Twitter flagged a tweet from President Trump for "glorifying violence." According to the company, "We've taken action in the interest of preventing others from being inspired to commit violent acts, but have kept the Tweet on Twitter because it is important that the public still be able to see the Tweet given its relevance to ongoing matters of public importance."

What The IBD Stock Checkup Says About Twitter Stock

According to the IBD Stock Checkup, Twitter stock has a 75 out of a highest-possible 99 IBD Composite Rating. Investors can use the Composite Rating to easily gauge the quality of a stock's fundamentals and technicals as well as fund ownership.

Join IBD experts as they analyze winning stocks on IBD Live every morning. Take a free trial!

Among the other proprietary IBD ratings, Twitter has a 60 out of a highest-possible 99 EPS Rating, a poor 56 out of a highest-possible 99 Relative Strength Rating and a B- Accumulation/Distribution Rating. The EPS Rating measures a company's fundamental strength by looking at quarterly and annual earnings growth.

The RS Rating measures a stock's price performance, while the Accumulation Rating gauges institutional demand over the past 13 weeks, with C being a neutral rating. Prefer those stocks with an A or B for Accumulation/Distribution; this indicates that mutual funds, banks, hedge funds, insurers, pension funds and the like are net buyers of the stock over the past three months.

Among Twitter's rivals, Snapchat parent Snap is breaking out above a cup with handle with a 18.56 buy point, while Facebook stock is above a 215.38 entry in a cup with handle.

Is TWTR Stock A Buy? Current Stock Chart Analysis

Amid a new stock market rally, Twitter shares are more than 30% off their 52-week high after a sharp rally in recent weeks. Shares are back below their 200-day line.

In conclusion, Twitter stock is not a buy right now in the coronavirus stock market rally amid significant weakness in stock price, but watch the stock to see if it continues to build its base.

For more leading stocks and stocks approaching buy points, check out these IBD Stock Lists, like the Stocks Near Buy Zones. To see the current stock market trend, check out IBD's signature daily analysis, The Big Picture.

Be sure to follow Scott Lehtonen on Twitter at @IBD_SLehtonen for more on growth stocks and the stock market.

      Is Twitter Stock A Buy Right Now? Here's What Earnings, Charts Show; Twitter-Trump Feud Escalates

      Licensing
      • SCOTT LEHTONEN
      • 06:11 PM ET 05/29/2020

      After a much-hyped IPO in November 2013, social media giant Twitter (TWTR) has struggled to maintain any significant stock price appreciation. Plus, Twitter's feud with President Trump continues to escalate.

      X

According to the company, "We've taken action in the interest of preventing others from being inspired to commit violent acts, but have kept the Tweet on Twitter because it is important that the public still be able to see the Tweet given its relevance to ongoing matters of public importance."
